entry.title: Parliament proposes to strip most opposition deputies of mandates

media:group.media:title: Parliament proposes to strip most opposition deputies of mandates
media:group.media:description:
üìçThe conditions for obtaining Armenian citizenship may be tightened. Applicants will be required to spend at least 60 days in the country during a period of two years. üìçThe United States fully supports the normalization process between Armenia and Turkey, the State Department said in a statement. üìçAnd the leadership council of Armenia‚Äôs parliament will convene a special session to discuss depriving certain opposition deputies of their mandates.

entry.title: Closing the gender gap in Armenia‚Äôs burgeoning tech sector

media:group.media:title: Closing the gender gap in Armenia‚Äôs burgeoning tech sector
media:group.media:description:
Seda Papoyan, the managing director of the Armenian chapter of Girls in Tech, a global non-profit seeking to close the gender gap in tech around the world, sat down with CivilNet to talk about the upcoming FemInno conference. The conference, which will take place on July 30-31 in Yerevan, will have over 30 speakers from around the world, as well as master classes and workshops. Papoyan discussed why the participation of women in tech is important, how the FemInno conference seeks to achieve better representation for women in tech, and why companies are realizing that diversity policies improve their chances of success.

entry.title: Armenia to establish foreign intelligence service

media:group.media:title: Armenia to establish foreign intelligence service
media:group.media:description:
üìçArmenia will establish a foreign intelligence service, said Security Council Secretary Armen Grigoryan. üìçAzerbaijani forces opened fire on Armenian military positions in the western part of the border, reported Armenia‚Äôs Defense Ministry. üìçPrime Minister Nikol Pashinyan held talks in Yerevan with Rwandan Foreign Minister Vincent Biruta.

entry.title: More Armenian villages targeted by Azerbaijan

media:group.media:title: More Armenian villages targeted by Azerbaijan
media:group.media:description:
On July 4, Azerbaijani forces opened fire in the direction of Armenia‚Äôs Khachik village. Only three days later, Azerbaijani forces again fired in the direction of another Armenian village, Yelpin. Armenia reported no casualties in either village, but the Khachik mayor‚Äôs car was damaged in the shooting. Khachik and Yelpin, both located along Armenia‚Äôs border with Nakhichevan, join a long list of Armenian villages and towns that have been targeted in this way since the end of the 2020 Karabakh war, causing angst among local residents.

media:group.media:description:
üìçArmenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan spoke directly with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan for the first time. üìçConstruction crews broke ground on the controversial Jesus Christ statue on Mount Hatis. üìçThe annual Golden Apricot international film festival began in Yerevan.
